resources.string: Get medical attention if there is blood or you suspect poisoning

string-array.name: diarrhoea_diagnosis
string-array.item: 1. Repeated passing of loose or watery stool.
2. Can include stomach ache, vomiting, headache and fever.

string-array.name: diarrhoea_responses
string-array.item: 1. Increase fluid intake.
2. Offer milk or oral re-hydration solution(ORS) to infants and young children.
3. Give small frequent meals.
4. Avoid fruit juice and fizzy drinks, as well as sugary foods.

resources.string: Get medical attention if you suspect poisoning

string-array.name: vomiting_diagnosis
string-array.item: 1. Involuntary expulsion of stomach contents through mouth or nose.
2. Can include stomach ache and diarrhoea.

string-array.name: vomiting_responses
string-array.item: 1. Increase fluid intake; give small sips at a time.
2. Offer popsicles (ice lollies) to avoid dehydration.
3. Avoid solid food for up to 6 hours or until vomiting subsides.
4. Avoid fruit juice and fizzy drinks.

resources.string: Do not move the child if bone is protruding or injury includes head/neck

string-array.name: fractures_diagnosis
string-array.item: 1. You heard a snap or grinding sound.
2. Swelling, bruising, or tenderness around the injured part.
3. Painful to touch or move.

string-array.name: fractures_responses
string-array.item: 1. Gently remove clothing from around injured area.
2. Apply a cold compress or ice pack wrapped in cloth. Do not put ice directly on the skin.
3. Keep limb in the position you find it.
4. Place soft padding around the injured part.
5. Get medical assistance.

resources.string: Get medical attention immediately if you cannot stop the bleeding in 5 minutes.

string-array.name: cuts_emergency
string-array.item: 1. Wound begins bleeding again after 5 minutes of continuously applying pressure.
2. Cut is on the child\'s face or neck.
3. Injury was caused by an animal or human bite, a burn, electrical injury, or puncture wound.
4. The cut appears to be deep.

string-array.name: cuts_responses
string-array.item: 1. Rinse the wound thoroughly with water to clean out dirt and debris.
2. Wash the wound with an antiseptic solution and water; rinse well.
3. Cover the wound with a sterile adhesive bandage or sterile gauze and adhesive tape.
4. If blood soaks through the gauze, do not remove it. Apply another gauze pad on top and continue applying pressure.

resources.string: Get immediate medical attention if burn is on the face, scalp, hands, joint surfaces, or genitals.

string-array.name: burns_diagnosis
string-array.item: 1. First degree burns: redness, pain, and minor swelling. The skin is dry without blisters.
2. Second-degree burns: blisters, severe pain, and redness.
3. Third degree burns: surface appears dry, looks waxy white, leathery, brown, or charred. There may be little or no pain or the area may feel numb at first because of nerve damage.

string-array.name: burns_responses
string-array.item: 1. Remove child from heat source.
2. Run cool(not cold) water over the area, or hold clean cold compress for 3 - 5 minutes.
3. Give child something for the pain.
4. Seek immediate medical attention for second and third degree burns.

resources.string: Get immediate medical attention if child has allergic reaction.

string-array.name: bites_diagnosis
string-array.item: 1. Bug bites and stings are usually just annoying, causing temporary discomfort and pain.

string-array.name: bites_responses
string-array.item: 1. Remove stinger if it\â€™s still visible.
2. Wash the area with an antiseptic solution and water.
3. Apply ice pack or cold compress for a few minutes.
4. Give child something for the pain.
5. Seek immediate medical attention if bite was caused by an animal or human.
